comment_body: @lguohan pls merge. For some miracle ++ was missed for 9.4
@lguohan  having problem resolving conflict for saitypes.h in the old PR, so I just started a new one. And saiobject.h has been taken care of. please check
@sonicyao1985 , can we stay on the #304 as it has all the approvals. Also there are still some questions on that PR. Can you reopen it?
supersede #325
Please install "grep" on test docker

@kcudnik 

"if you change SAI_WRED_ATTR_RED_ENABLE dynamically, then it may happen that those red threshold min/max is no longer required (if you sed enable to false) but attributes were passed already, those should be actually "validonlywhen" rather than conditions, currently this option is not available in metadata yet, i will work on it in near future, for now you can comment out those conditions with comments

also there will be a problem when you enable RED but thresholds are not set, so they should have default value specified"

Based on your comments, i added validonly flag, it is correct or you are going to add vlaidonlywhen flag.
for can i comment condition and vlaidonly ?

https://sonic-jenkins.westus.cloudapp.azure.com/job/sai-meta-pr-build/234/console
your build failed, please correct, i have mistake on my valid only logic, which fix is PR now,
also please remove spaces at the end of every line
rebuild test
Done
@kcudnik - Please review
@lguohan, @atitjain @itaibaz - Please review
@kcudnik, please review.
saiport.h there is attribute SAI_PORT_ATTR_PORT_VLAN_ID which is uint16 should be probably also converted to object id
@lguohan @kcudnik - saiport.h , saiacl.h etc as per previous discussions we leave it as uint16.
Was looking for this during our development. Really helpful will approve.
Please add 'dot' graphviz to build environment
test rebuild after add graphviz
@AshokDaparthi , @kcudnik , please review.
@kcudnik , this commit was lost in commit 072d6147a8409e0b96395cb4bcdf07c5f51b6991
@lguohan - Could you please add the counters to retrieve the shred headroom counters.
@AshokDaparthi , will do that in a different PR.

@kcudnik , @itaibaz , @atitjain , @AshokDaparthi , @tushar-ty , @SathishKumarTR-Dell , @krambn
please review
@kcudnik , can you review?
@tushar-ty , @itaibaz , @atitjain , @krambn, @AshokDaparthi , @SathishKumarTR-Dell , @sonicyao1985 , please review.
Add bulk route_entry create/remove also ?

@atitjain , this function pointer is also universal to all UID based object. For other key based object, we can later introduce the bulk function for each type as the existing create object function.
@kcudnik , batch route will be added later.
@lguohan pls review. It present in master but 0.9.4. lack of it.  sai_thrift_vlan_remove_all_ports use this function.
test
test account
test
plan to check-in by the end of this week.
@lguohan @itaibaz @atitjain @tushar-ty @mattyk - Please review
rebuild
This will close #232
ok to test
:shipit:
@itaibaz @tushar-ty @lguohan @atitjain - Please review
ack
@itaibaz , @atitjain @lguohan @tushar-ty - Please review
@krambn please review
@tushar-ty , @AshokDaparthi , @atitjain , @krambn, @zubinshah please review.
Looks like we are good here? Plan to check-in by the end of this week.

The meaning is there can be up to one object instance of a given type
For example, there can be exactly zero or one trap object of type BGP. It is not allowed to create 2 objects of trap type BGP, as both would be managing the behavior for the same trap.

From: Ashok Daparthi [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Wednesday, November 09, 2016 10:57 PM
To: opencomputeproject/SAI SAI@noreply.github.com
Cc: Itai Baz itaib@mellanox.com; Mention mention@noreply.github.com
Subject: Re: [opencomputeproject/SAI] host if spec changes for 1.0 (#266)

@AshokDaparthi commented on this pull request.

---

In inc/saihostintf.hhttps://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/266:

> @@ -148,16 +148,26 @@ typedef sai_status_t(*sai_get_hostif_trap_group_attribute_fn)(

```
     _Inout_ sai_attribute_t *attr_list);
```

 /**

+\* @brief Host interface user defined trap type table range

+*/

+#define SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_TABLE_RANGE 0x1

@lguohanhttps://github.com/lguohan @kcudnikhttps://github.com/kcudnik @itaibazhttps://github.com/itaibaz -
/**
- @briefhttps://github.com/brief Host interface trap type []
  *
- @typehttps://github.com/type sai_hostif_trap_type_t
- @flagshttps://github.com/flags MANDATORY_ON_CREATE | CREATE_ONLY | KEY
  */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_ATTR_TRAP_TYPE = SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_ATTR_START,

What was meaning of KEY here, will SAI allow creating only object with this TYPE or it just indication to application like this is input for creating object.

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/266, or mute the threadhttps://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJ9nYtgu7CaOtybAWkgqhQf8tjkW31Wnks5q8sA0gaJpZM4KbzSd.

There is just a single enum set :

/**
- @brief Attribute data for SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_ATTR_CHANNEL_TYPE
  _/
  typedef enum _sai_hostif_table_entry_channel_type_t
  {
  /_\* receive packets via callback */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_CB,
  
  /*\* receive packets via file descriptor */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_FD,
  
  /*\* receive packets via Linux netdev type port */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_PHYSICAL_PORT,
  
  /*\* receive packets via Linux netdev logical port (LAG or port) */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_LOGICAL_PORT,
  
  /*\* receive packets via Linux netdev L3 interface */
  SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_L3

} sai_hostif_table_entry_channel_type_t;

You might be seeing in the history the older enum set, that was renamed

From: Tushar Tyagi [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: Thursday, November 10, 2016 9:53 AM
To: opencomputeproject/SAI SAI@noreply.github.com
Cc: Itai Baz itaib@mellanox.com; Mention mention@noreply.github.com
Subject: Re: [opencomputeproject/SAI] host if spec changes for 1.0 (#266)

@tushar-ty commented on this pull request.

---

In inc/saihostintf.hhttps://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/266:

> +
-    /*\* End of custom range base */
-    SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_ATTR_CUSTOM_RANGE_END

+

+} sai_hostif_table_entry_attr_t;

+

+/**

+\* @brief Create host interface table entry

+*

+\* @param[out] hif_table_entry Host interface table entry

+\* @param[in] attr_count Number of attributes

+\* @param[in] attr_list Aarray of attributes

+*

+\* @return #SAI_STATUS_SUCCESS on success Failure status code on error

+*/

+typedef sai_status_t(*sai_create_hostif_table_entry_fn)(

The following enum lists look pretty redundant, could they not be consolidated ?

/**

·         @briefhttps://github.com/brief Attribute data for SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_ATTR_CHANNEL_TYPE
/
typedef enum _sai_host_interface_table_entry_channel_type_t
{
/\* receive packets via callback */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_CB,

/*\* receive packets via file descriptor */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_FD,

/*\* receive packets via Linux netdev type port */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_PHYSICAL_PORT,

/*\* receive packets via Linux netdev logical port (LAG or port) */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_LOGICAL_PORT,

/*\* receive packets via Linux netdev L3 interface */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_L3

} sai_host_interface_table_entry_channel_type_t;

/*

·         Attribute data for SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY
/
typedef enum _sai_host_interface_table_user_channel
{
/ for user channel callback /
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_CB,
/ for user channel file descriptor */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_FD,

/\* for user channel physical port */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_NET_PHY_PORT,

/\* for user channel logical port */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_NET_LOGICAL_PORT,

/\* for user channel L3 intarface */
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_NET_L3,

} sai_host_interface_table_user_channel_t;

No,

I’m seeing this with history turned off in the specification section.

```
/*host intarfce table entry action channel  [
```

sai_host_interface_table_entry_channel_type_t]

```
 Valid only when
```

SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_ACTION_USER_CHANNEL_TYPE ==
SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_ENTRY_USER_CHANNEL_FD

```
 * (MANDATORY_ON_CREATE | CREATE_ONLY)  */

 SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_ACTION_CHANNEL,





/*host intarfce table entry action user channel type [
```

sai_host_interface_table_user_channel_t]

```
 * (MANDATORY_ON_CREATE | CREATE_ONLY)  */

 SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_ACTION_USER_CHANNEL_TYPE,
```

And the following in the examples:

sai_if_channel_attr[2].id= SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_ATTR_CHANNEL;

sai_if_channel_attr[2].value=SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_CHANNEL_TYPE_NETDEV_LOGICAL_PORT;

sai_create_hostif_table_entry_fn(&host_table_entry[0], 3,
sai_if_channel_attr);

It’s a bit confusing to understand.

-thanks

I’m seeing this with history turned off in the specification section.

sai_host_interface_table_entry_channel_type_t]

sai_host_interface_table_user_channel_t]
- (MANDATORY_ON_CREATE | CREATE_ONLY) */

SAI_HOST_INTERFACE_TABLE_ENTRY_ACTION_USER_CHANNEL_TYPE,

And the following in the examples:

sai_if_channel_attr[2].id= SAI_HOSTIF_TABLE_ENTRY_ATTR_CHANNEL;

In inc/saihostintf.hhttps://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/266#pullrequestreview-9814970:

> @@ -861,8 +956,6 @@ typedef struct _sai_hostif_api_t

```
 sai_remove_hostif_trap_fn                      remove_trap;

 sai_set_hostif_trap_attribute_fn               set_trap_attribute;

 sai_get_hostif_trap_attribute_fn               get_trap_attribute;
```
-    sai_set_hostif_user_defined_trap_attribute_fn  set_user_defined_trap_attribute;
-    sai_get_hostif_user_defined_trap_attribute_fn  get_user_defined_trap_attribute;
  
   sai_recv_hostif_packet_fn                      recv_packet;
  
   sai_send_hostif_packet_fn                      send_packet;

How to get Switch ID in CB mode ( hif_id == SAI_NULL_OBJECT_ID )?

/**
-   @briefhttps://github.com/brief Hostif send function
  *
-   @paramhttps://github.com/param[in] hif_id Host interface id. only valid for send through FD channel. Use #SAI_NULL_OBJECT_ID for send through CB channel.
-   @paramhttps://github.com/param[in] buffer Packet buffer
-   @paramhttps://github.com/param[in] buffer size Packet size in bytes
-   @paramhttps://github.com/param[in] attr_count Number of attributes
-   @paramhttps://github.com/param[in] attr_list Array of attributes
  *
-   @returnhttps://github.com/return #SAI_STATUS_SUCCESS on success Failure status code on error
  _/
  typedef sai_status_t(_sai_send_hostif_packet_fn)(
  In sai_object_id_t hif_id,
  In void *buffer,
  In sai_size_t buffer_size,
  In uint32_t attr_count,
  In sai_attribute_t *attr_list);

Its not very clear whats the functional outcome of binding to a lag or intf or tunnel ?
It seems its eventually going to act as a filter or qualifier just like for a port and vlan.
If not then whats the difference between binding to a port vs Lag ?
If yes then things become unclear for router interface and tunnel – as those objects come in various flavors/types and are constructed out of several params/attributes – is the expectation to physically match all those attributes ?
Pls clarify.

-thanks

To answer your question in brief "Whats the difference say between binding to a port vs a lag ?"
- when an ACL is applied to a port all traffic igress-ing into that port : goes through the filter checks (and corresponding actions)
- when an ACL is applied to a LAG all traffic ingressing on the LAG/BOND :  goes through the filter checks (and corresponding actions)
- same goes through other binding points : namely RIFs/TUNNELS/Etc.

Also, to clarify the abstract idea behind any bind point is to map them to the SAI pipeline’s logical stage. In the SAI logical pipeline (or even in a switch silicon’s pipeline) there is a point in the various stages where a packet can be clearly identified for services to be applied for :
- ports
- LAGs (for ingress lag properties or egress)
- RIFs (layer 3 interface properties , like v4/v6 routing enable or disable, etc..)
  — and so on other interfaces like ingress tunnels, etc.

The idea that applications can simply create ACL tables (like in iptables, or openswitch CLI or cisco like NOSes)..
- access-lists 1 , with specific rules.
  These access lists created can be bound to logical interfaces independent of any rules or match/key/mask they are programmed with . HENCE the packets ingressing (or egressing) through these logical interfaces would be subject to rules and match/action criteria specified in "access-list 1".

Something on the lines of cisco like configuration also mentioned in the openswitch forums as well :
- http://lists.openswitch.net/pipermail/ops-dev/2015-December/000659.html
- http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5000/sw/configuration/guide/cli/CLIConfigurationGuide/sec_ipacls.html

So you do agree that the lag binding point also creates a Lag value match|filter criteria, just like port - which would mean that compared to the existing spec this is a new filter - right.

I understand that you are describing things from the CLI/NOS point of view. But i'm trying to understand the details from the SAI/SDK/hw implementation point of view. And I need to know that when a ACL group is bound to another complex SAI object like a router intf or Tunnel what are the physical match criteria that get created. I think the spec does not clearly indicate this.

Its not very clear whats the functional outcome of binding to a lag or intf or tunnel ?

> > Zubin : the functional or logical outcome of applying an ACL table to a lag or rif  or tunnel -> is to subject any flow or traffic specifically classified to be ingress on a LAG or RIF or TUNNEL be applied or subject to the ACL table (or GROUP) created by the user distinctly.

It seems its eventually going to act as a filter or qualifier just like for a port and vlan.

> > the difference between that we can enable applications and other ASIC architecture agnostic vendors to move the qualifiers out of the filter rules.

If not then whats the difference between binding to a port vs Lag ?

> > Biggest difference is to avoid the logistics of managing the port vs lag : states and awareness in the NOS. NOS can abstract security services using “interfaces” and let the SAI implementation handle these interface to ACL rule management. - SCALABILITY AND FLEXIBILITY IN SAI abstraction.

If yes then things become unclear for router interface and tunnel – as those objects are constructed out of several params/attributes – is the expectation to physically match all those attributes ?

> > To clarify : the packets classified to be ingressing on a RIF or TUNNELS are well defined in SAI as well as mostly all switch silicon. Since these objects may be constructed out of several parameters and attributes — in one silicon they can be completely be handled in a different fashion in another switch silicon. hence, it makes sense to abstractly define them in SAI abstract definition and let the users of SAI manage them flexibly .

I think this is a big problem if the behavior is ambiguous and the app does not know the outcome of a specific SAI API call. 

> If yes then things become unclear for router interface and tunnel – as those objects are constructed out of several params/attributes – is the expectation to physically match all those attributes ?
> …
> 
> > To clarify : the packets classified to be ingressing on a RIF or TUNNELS are well defined in SAI as well as mostly all switch silicon. Since these objects may be constructed out of several parameters and attributes — in one silicon they can be completely be handled in a different fashion in another switch silicon. hence, it makes sense to abstractly define them in SAI abstract definition and let the users of SAI manage them flexibly .

Completely agree on the first part. “ lag binding point also creates a Lag value match|filter criteria, just like port” - But you see thats very hardware or implementation specific to your switch silicon. There are other switch silicon that may implement the same qualifiers in completely different fashion. And to let the SAI users expose to these level of details is not reasonable. Hence it is better to abstract general switch concepts - (interfaces) ports, lags, rifs, tunnels, bridge interface, etc. and handle them within SAI implementations. I will clarify those details in the specification, but i believe these abstract concepts are already part of SAI object starting from SAI 0.9.1 releases and some even before.

Looking at the spec before pre-1.0.0 as i mentioned in my presentation we never had any qualifiers. For eg. creating a port qualifier was never mandatory nor expected. So from that perspective all the attributes I added inside port, lag, rif, switch, tunnel, bridge interfaces are new.

When an ACL group or ACL table is bound to any complex (but well abstracted) SAI object — it definitely creates several physical match criteria - completely relevant for Broadcom ASIC and will be completely different in Cavium or other ASICs.

Ok, so the Lag binding point is very clear now.

I'm still struggling to get a clear picture from the new proposal about the complex objects like Router intf and Tunnel - I think we need to explicitly mention if 'all' the attributes of the particular object will be matched upon or only 'some' could be matched upon - depending on the ASIC. 
May be one of those is your assumption but not documenting this and leaving the behavior open ended is going to create confusion for the app writer and SAI implementer alike.

@tushar-ty -- This proposal does not introduce any new terminology or concepts within SAI by reusing the bind points. IMO RIFs and Tunnels are well defined objects that can be classified by the attributes these objects are defined - sairouterintf.h and saitunnel.h.

If identifying the router interface (and the flow) in a asic is well defined , i believe applying filters to those interfaces should , and applying filters to that object should be straight forward. I was assuming this approach for binding model - to rely on other specifications/and documents in SAI would have clarified those concepts - RIF and Tunnel. However, i will document this in the spec update.

probably to simplify the binding points, we can remove the tunnel related binding because after tunnel decap or encap, the packet will go to either a router or a bridge for further processing in the logical pipeline. Thus, we can bind the acl to the ingress bridge port or router port after the tunnel to match those packets. See SAI_proposal_Bridge_port_v0.2.docx, figure 4.3.

I am thinking to introduce an acl table group member object, and move these two attributes into the member object.

here is how the API works:
1. create_acl_table_group.
2. create_acl_table
3. create_acl_table_group_member

In acl_table_group_member, you specify the acl_table_id, and acl_table_group_id.

The group_member has an attribute PRIORITY which is to define the priority of acl table within the group, and it is only valid when the group type is sequential.

Could you please elaborate more on changes done?
What is the purpose of adding front_port_to_hw_lanes mapping?
The purpose is to create a generic test environment that will work on all platforms and with all cable connectivity setups.

thanks. I am wondering because now PTF client does not longer work with following message:
_SystemExit: No ptf interface<-> switch front port mapping, please specify as parameter or in external file_

That's because PTF client now expects either port_map or port_map_file.
Could you please provide an example of PTF client command line?

This is Correct. You can see an example for this map in msn_2700 subfolder /saitests/src/msn_2700.

As for the command line: you have two options:
1. -t "port_map='0@Ethernet0,1@Ethernet1'" according to your cable connectivity.  This will map the ptf interface to a front port of the switch.
2. -t "port_map_file='FILE_LOCATION'". As I mentioned earlier you have an example for this file in msn subfolder.

This way, and with the front_port to hw_lanes map that the saiserver receives on startup, the port_list is always sorted with the ptf interface as an index ( port_list[PTF INTERFACE]  )

And I also added a list called front_port_list that is sorted according to the switch front ports.

Is this intended to trap packets without binding the route to a local RIF? 
I guess the packet has to be mapped to a RIF and classified to a VRF and so the SAI model requires to bind the route to a local RIF (Port/VLAN/Loopback) to trap the self destined packets to CPU. So, this looks like adding a redundant case.

this is to provide meta data (class) for certain route which can be used in later stage for classification. In this case, for the BGP trap we'd like only to match the bgp traffic with dest ip equal to one of our interface ip or loopback ip while src/dst port = 179. 

The IP2ME route will trap those packets to CPU while add those meta data, so that later stage can use the meta data information to do the match.

We also thought about using the meta data approach in SAI. But that approach seems to be too generic for this specific problem and asic platform may various in terms of this IP2ME implementation. One specific problem that this meta does not really propogate to acl on certain platforms. Therefore, we prefer to use this way to solve this problem.
thanks

Hello Itai,

A general suggestion: please, add a section to describe what happens when
the port is removed from a LAG.

For example, initially a port was not a member of a LAG and had an
attribute (e.g. SAI_PORT_ATTR_PORT_VLAN_ID) set to the value 5. The
LAG has SAI_PORT_ATTR_PORT_VLAN_ID
value as 7. The port was added to the LAG and later removed from it. Should
SAI restore the value of SAI_PORT_ATTR_PORT_VLAN_ID to 5?

I would prefer this to be a common, rather than case-by-case policy.

Another general suggestion is to describe the basic principle how you
decided whether to allow LAG ports to have individual values or not.

In the mirroring section you might have missed an attribute:
SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_MONITOR_PORT

Thanks,
Vladimir

Hi Vladimir,
Sorry for the delay in response

I will add the following details to our proposal :

·         Pure bridge attributes (.1q) are applicable only for a LAG, and not for a port which is a member of a LAG

·         When an attribute is not a pure bridge one, it is applicable both for a LAG and a member port.

·         When a port joins a LAG, it inherits from the LAG the pure bridge attributes configuration, meaning we are aligning these settings from the LAG to the new member port

·         When a port leaves a LAG :
1. ```
     Pure bridge attributes will be set to the default values in SAI spec
   ```
2. ```
     The rest of the attributes will remain as is
   ```

·         SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_MONITOR_PORT added for the mirroring section

Thanks

On Wed, Apr 27, 2016 at 6:35 AM, Itai Baz notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hi Vladimir,
> Sorry for the delay in response
> 
> I will add the following details to our proposal :
> 
> · Pure bridge attributes (.1q) are applicable only for a LAG, and not for
> a port which is a member of a LAG
> 
> · When an attribute is not a pure bridge one, it is applicable both for a
> LAG and a member port.
> 
> · When a port joins a LAG, it inherits from the LAG the pure bridge
> attributes configuration, meaning we are aligning these settings from the
> LAG to the new member port
> 
> · When a port leaves a LAG :
> 1. Pure bridge attributes will be set to the default values in SAI spec
> 2. The rest of the attributes will remain as is
> 
> · SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_MONITOR_PORT added for the mirroring section
> 
> Thanks
>

Hi ,

  We already have all necessary information to operate with VLAN/port pair in SAI adapter client. The VLAN member is a bit synthetic instance which adding some extra complexity, isn't it? Isn't better just to add function which checks if port belongs to VLAN?

@rivasiv The design rationale is explained in the https://github.com/lguohan/SAI/blob/uom/doc/SAI-Proposal-7-UOID.md 

@tushar-ty to optimize the performance, in the future, we'd like to have an API to do batch SAI object creation which allows user to create multiple sai object in one function call.

Hi @lguohan , 

  I understand UOID conception, but 

  LAG_member and VLAN member sounds synthetic for me :
-  for example LAG is logical interface(it is complete, self managed instance) all it properties are consistent and suppose to be the same for all LAG members, so do we really need to have LAG_member object, operate with it as with single instance? Are there any real use case for this?  
  Why we can not operate with single LAG object? That's more natural way, isn't it ?
  - we do not have a way to get VLAN from VLAN_member as UOID API conception doesn't provide such possibility(as UOID creation algorithm suppose to be vendor specific). So to operate with VLAN_member  
    we still need to keep VLAN/VLAN_member map in client application. Are there any benefits of one more extra object(VLAN_member) ?  

Thanks,
   Rostyslav

hi 
I have 2 problems.
1, how to add PE port to VLAN, it should be easy to extend "sai_add_ports_to_vlan_fn". but my main concern is the "remote replication";
2, considering chip performance and chip capability, can you add some FLAG to get "remote replication " capability on SAI.
and then, when user want to "add port to vlan", user should consider the chip capability and performance. user can add PE port to VLAN for CB replication or add Cascade port to VLAN for PE replication.

another concern is IPMC, if user use CB replication, it is easy to support it. but if user want to use PE replication, it is a issue. currently, SAI don't support IPMC, but i think we need consider it later.

Hi Chen,
1. The addition of the PE ports to the VLAN will be taken care by the communication between the control planes in CB and PE. The CB control plane will send control message to the control plane in PE to add the PE ports to the vlan. The applications running in the PE will then invoke the SAI vlan api to add the ports to the vlan in the PE. 
2. The replication/flooding will be handled using Multicast ECID. If replication is desired in CB, then CB will send multiple copies on the Cascading port, with each copy carrying the unicast ECID of the PE port. If replication is desired in PE, then CB will send one copy per Cascading port with the Vlan's Multicast ECID. The control plane will program the PE data plane, to replicate the frames based on the Multicast ECID.

For IPMC, separate ECID must be assigned to each Multicast group.

The PE ports will be instantiated in the CB as extended ports. There is no need to program any port attributes for these extended ports in CB data plane.

Hi Rsivasankar
1,but if the replication is desired in CB, then extend port(ECID) should be added to VLAN on CB. here, the current SAI don't support add extend port(ECID) to vlan. 
or can you give me an example to do that?
2, if the replication is desired in PE, yes you are right that Control plane can handle it on PE. but on CB, how can we add Cascade port to VLAN. maybe we should consider that using 1br_port_object_id with Cascade type to "add_to_vlan".
3, for IPMC, it is also related with "remote replication" option. if IPMC replication is performed in CB, there are no problem. if IPMC replication is performed in PE, a Multicast ECID should be assigned to that IPMC group as you said. but in this case, we must consider that PE should copied the IPMC packet VLAN by VLAN. it is means the IPMC packets is flooded in multiple VLAN.
4, if you can add a switch attribute to describe the ASIC "remote replication" capability, it is convenient for my customer to design system.

Hi Chen,

Please see my responses inlined...

1,but if the replication is desired in CB, then extend port(ECID) should be added to VLAN on CB. here, the current SAI don't support add extend port(ECID) to vlan. 
or can you give me an example to do that?
[Ravi] I missed this part. The Extended port must also be added in the Vlan in the CB. The current  
          SAI add vlan port API takes the list of ports (object). The 1br_port_object_id can also be 
          allowed. So we can bring this support without changing the vlan api.  

2, if the replication is desired in PE, yes you are right that Control plane can handle it on PE. but on CB, how can we add Cascade port to VLAN. maybe we should consider that using 1br_port_object_id with Cascade type to "add_to_vlan".
[Ravi] SAI can implicitly add the Cascade Port to the Vlan (or) we can mandate that the application 
          must do this explicitly. For replication in PE, CB must transmit the frame on the cascading 
          port with the Vlan's Multicast ECID. So we need to associate the Multicast ECID to the Vlan. 
          This is missed in my proposal. I will add an ECID attribute in the vlan object.

3, for IPMC, it is also related with "remote replication" option. if IPMC replication is performed in CB, there are no problem. if IPMC replication is performed in PE, a Multicast ECID should be assigned to that IPMC group as you said. but in this case, we must consider that PE should copied the IPMC packet VLAN by VLAN. it is means the IPMC packets is flooded in multiple VLAN.
[Ravi] I have to correct my previous statement on this. We should assign one Multicast Ecid for 
          each vlan in a Multicast group. This is because, the PE will forward the packets based on 
          ECID only. It will not look into the vlan id present in the packet. 

```
      Let us say there are 3 PE ports ExP1V1, ExP2V1 and ExP3V2. 
      ExP1V1 and ExP2V1 are in vlan V1, while ExP3V2 is in V2. 
      Let the Multicast ECIDs assigned to the Vlans in this Multicast Group be ECID-Mc-V1 and 
      ECID-Mc-V2 (Note ECID-Mc-V1 and ECID-Mc-V2 are different than the ECIDs assigned to
      Vlans V1 and V2 for flooding purpose). 
      Let the cascading port through which the PE is reachable be CP.

      CB should transmit 2 packets on CP as follows:
      Packet 1: Vlan = V1, ECID = ECID-Mc-V1
      Packet 2: Vlan = V2, ECID = ECID-Mc-V2

      PE must be programmed such that,
          Packet with ECID-Mc-V1 is sent on Ports ExP1V1 and ExP2V1
          Packet with ECID-Mc-V2 is sent on Port ExP1V2
```

4, if you can add a switch attribute to describe the ASIC "remote replication" capability, it is convenient for my customer to design system.
[Ravi] This can be added. We can discuss this in detail during the meeting.

hi Ravi,

good, it's cleared. specially, I accept your idea for IPMC replication.

SAI_ROUTE_ATTR_NEXT_HOP_ID can be set with RIF Id for the directly reachable route, as mentioned in the comments. So, do we need the new ON_LINK next-hop type which requires the software to create a dummy next-hop id - as this does not get programmed in hardware. Can the NEIGHBOR_MISS_PACKET_ACTION be added as an attribute like ON_LINK_ROUTE_NEIGHBOR_MISS_PACKET_ACTION in the route entry itself?

NEIGHBOR_MISS_PACKET_ACTION is an attribute that controls the behavior in the neighbor lookup phase, it does not happen in the route lookup phase. So, better not to put that attribute in route entry itself. 

However, the another option is to still keep current header but add the neighbor_miss_packet_action in the route interface itself. 

So, the route entry still points itself next_hop_id to a router interface in the direct reachable route case, then we have an attribute in the router interface to control the missing neighbor action. Does this sound ok?
Agreed. This looks fine.
